010package imagingbook.pub.geometry.mappings.linear;
011
012import imagingbook.lib.math.Arithmetic;
013import imagingbook.lib.math.Matrix;
014import imagingbook.lib.settings.PrintPrecision;
015import imagingbook.pub.geometry.basic.Pnt2d;
016import imagingbook.pub.geometry.basic.Pnt2d.PntDouble;
017import imagingbook.pub.geometry.fitting.ProjectiveFit2D;
018
019
020/**
021 * This class represents a projective transformation in 2D (also known
022 * as a "homography"). It can be specified uniquely by four pairs of corresponding
023 * points.
024 * It can be assumed that every instance of this class is indeed a projective mapping.
025 */
026public class ProjectiveMapping2D extends LinearMapping2D {
027        
028        //  static methods -----------------------------------------------------
029        
030        /**
031         * Creates a projective 2D mapping from two sequences of corresponding points.
032         * If 4 point pairs are specified, the mapping is exact, otherwise a
033         * minimum least-squares fit is calculated.
034         * @param P the source points
035         * @param Q the target points
036         * @return a new projective mapping for the two point sets
037         */
038        public static ProjectiveMapping2D fromPoints(Pnt2d[] P, Pnt2d[] Q) {
039                ProjectiveFit2D fit = new ProjectiveFit2D(P, Q);
040                return new ProjectiveMapping2D(fit.getTransformationMatrix());
041        }
042        
043//      /**

045//       * 2D points.

049//       */

084//              double S = (x1 - x2) * (y3 - y2) - (x3 - x2) * (y1 - y2);
085//              if (Arithmetic.isZero(S)) {
086//                      throw new ArithmeticException("fromUnitSquareTo4Points(): division by zero!");
087//              }
088//              double a20 = ((x0 - x1 + x2 - x3) * (y3 - y2) - (y0 - y1 + y2 - y3) * (x3 - x2)) / S;
089//              double a21 = ((y0 - y1 + y2 - y3) * (x1 - x2) - (x0 - x1 + x2 - x3) * (y1 - y2)) / S;
090//              double a00 = x1 - x0 + a20 * x1;
091//              double a01 = x3 - x0 + a21 * x3;
092//              double a02 = x0;

094//              double a11 = y3 - y0 + a21 * y3;

096//              return new ProjectiveMapping2D(a00, a01, a02, a10, a11, a12, a20, a21);
097//      }

099//      /**

104//       * @param p3 point 3 of source quad P

110//       */

169//      }
170        
171        //  constructors -----------------------------------------------------
172        
173        /**
174         * Creates the identity mapping.
175         */
176        public ProjectiveMapping2D() {
177                super();
178        }
179        
180        /**
181         * Creates a projective mapping from a transformation matrix A,
182         * of arbitrary size. All relevant elements of A are inserted into
183         * actual 3x3 transformation matrix, except element (2,2) which
184         * is ignored and always set to 1 (to keep the transformation projective).
185         * If A is larger than 3 x 3, the remaining elements are ignored.
186         * 
187         * @param A a transformation matrix of arbitrary size
188         */
189        public ProjectiveMapping2D(double[][] A) {
190                //this(new LinearMapping2D(A));
191                super(extractProjectiveMatrix(A));
192        }
193        
194        private static double[][] extractProjectiveMatrix(double[][] A) {
195                double[][] M = Matrix.idMatrix(3);
196                final int m = Math.min(3, A.length);    // max. 3 rows
197                for (int i = 0; i < m; i++) {
198                        final int n = Math.min(3, A[i].length); // max. 3 columns
199                        for (int j = 0; j < n; j++) {
200                                M[i][j] = A[i][j];
201                        }
202                }
203                M[2][2] = 1;
204                return M;
205        }
206
207        
208        /**
209         * Creates a projective mapping from the specified matrix elements.
210         * @param a00 matrix element A_00
211         * @param a01 matrix element A_01
212         * @param a02 matrix element A_02
213         * @param a10 matrix element A_10
214         * @param a11 matrix element A_11
215         * @param a12 matrix element A_12
216         * @param a20 matrix element A_20
217         * @param a21 matrix element A_21
218         */
219        public ProjectiveMapping2D(
220                        double a00, double a01, double a02, 
221                        double a10, double a11, double a12, 
222                        double a20, double a21) {
223                super(a00, a01, a02, a10, a11, a12, a20, a21, 1);
224        }
225        
226        /**
227         * Creates a projective mapping from any linear mapping.
228         * The transformation matrix gets normalized to a22 = 1.
229         * @param m a linear mapping
230         */
231        public ProjectiveMapping2D(LinearMapping2D m) {
232                this(m.normalize());
233        }
234        
235        /**
236         * Creates a projective mapping from an existing instance.
237         * @param m a projective mapping
238         */
239        public ProjectiveMapping2D(ProjectiveMapping2D m) {
240                //this(m.getTransformationMatrix());
241                this(m.a00, m.a01, m.a02, m.a10, m.a11, m.a12, m.a20, m.a21);
242        }
243        
244        // ----------------------------------------------------------
245        
246        /**
247         * Concatenates this mapping A with another linear mapping B and returns
248         * a new mapping C, such that C(x) = B(A(x)).
249         * @param B the second mapping
250         * @return the concatenated mapping
251         */
252        public ProjectiveMapping2D concat(ProjectiveMapping2D B) {
253                LinearMapping2D C = LinearMapping2D.concatenate(B, this);
254                return new ProjectiveMapping2D(C);
255        }
256        
257        /**
258         * {@inheritDoc}
259         * @return a new projective mapping
260         */
261        public ProjectiveMapping2D duplicate() {
262                return new ProjectiveMapping2D(this);
263        }
264        
265        /**
266         * {@inheritDoc}
267         * Note that the inverse A' of a projective transformation matrix A is again a linear transformation
268         * but its a'2' element is generally not 1. Scaling A' to A'' = A' / a22' yields a projective transformation
269         * that reverses A. While A * A' = I, the result of A * A'' is a scaled identity matrix.
270         * @return the inverse projective transformation
271         */
272        public ProjectiveMapping2D getInverse() {
273                return new ProjectiveMapping2D(super.getInverse());
274        }
275        
276        @Override
277        public double[][] getJacobian(Pnt2d xy) {
278                // see Baker 2003 "20 Years" Part 1, Eq. 99 (p. 46)
279                final double x = xy.getX();
280                final double y = xy.getY();
281                final double a = a00 * x + a01 * y + a02;       // = alpha
282                final double b = a10 * x + a11 * y + a12;       // = beta
283                final double c = a20 * x + a21 * y + 1;         // = gamma
284                if (Arithmetic.isZero(c)) {
285                        throw new ArithmeticException("getJacobian(): division by zero!");
286                }
287                final double cc = c * c;
288                return new double[][]
289                        {{x/c, y/c, 0,   0,   -(x*a)/cc, -(y*a)/cc, 1/c, 0  },
290                         {0,   0,   x/c, y/c, -(x*b)/cc, -(y*b)/cc, 0,   1/c}};
291        }
292        
293        // -----------------------------------------------------------------
294        
295        /**
296         * For testing only.
297         * @param args ignored
298         */
299        public static void main(String[] args) {
300                PrintPrecision.set(6);
301
302                // book example:
303                Pnt2d[] P = {
304                                PntDouble.from(2, 5),
305                                PntDouble.from(4, 6),
306                                PntDouble.from(7, 9),
307                                PntDouble.from(5, 9),
308                                PntDouble.from(5.2, 9.1)        // 5 points, overdetermined!
309                                };
310                
311                Pnt2d[] Q = {
312                                PntDouble.from(4, 3),
313                                PntDouble.from(5, 2),
314                                PntDouble.from(9, 3),
315                                PntDouble.from(7, 5),
316                                PntDouble.from(7, 4.9)  // 5 points, overdetermined!
317                                };
318                
319                ProjectiveMapping2D pm = ProjectiveMapping2D.fromPoints(P, Q);
320                
321                System.out.println("\nprojective mapping = \n" + pm.toString());
322                
323                for (int i = 0; i < P.length; i++) {
324                        Pnt2d Bi = pm.applyTo(P[i]);
325                        System.out.println(P[i].toString() + " -> " + Bi.toString());
326                }
327                
328                System.out.println("pm is of class " + pm.getClass().getName());
329                ProjectiveMapping2D pmi = pm.getInverse();
330                pmi = pmi.normalize();
331                System.out.println("\ninverse projective mapping (normalized) = \n" + pmi.toString());
332                
333                for (int i = 0; i < Q.length; i++) {
334                        Pnt2d Ai = pmi.applyTo(Q[i]);
335                        System.out.println(Q[i].toString() + " -> " + Ai.toString());
336                }
337                
338                ProjectiveMapping2D testId = pm.concat(pmi);
339                System.out.println("\ntest: should be a scaled identity matrix: = \n" + testId.toString());
340        }
341        /*
342         projective mapping = 
343        {{-0.732424, 1.208712, 0.244379}, 
344        {-1.702388, 1.725545, -1.654658}, 
345        {-0.206047, 0.123181, 1.000000}}
346        Point[2,000, 5,000] -> Point[4,007, 2,964]
347        Point[4,000, 6,000] -> Point[4,992, 2,065]
348        Point[7,000, 9,000] -> Point[8,999, 2,939]
349        Point[5,000, 9,000] -> Point[6,918, 4,973]
350        Point[5,200, 9,100] -> Point[7,084, 4,950]
351        pm is of class imagingbook.pub.geometry.mappings.linear.ProjectiveMapping2D
352        
353        inverse projective mapping (normalized) = 
354        {{2.430345, -1.484645, -3.050507}, 
355        {2.573894, -0.859176, -2.050649}, 
356        {0.183712, -0.200073, 1.000000}}
357        Point[4,000, 3,000] -> Point[1,954, 4,995]
358        Point[5,000, 2,000] -> Point[4,038, 5,993]
359        Point[9,000, 3,000] -> Point[6,998, 9,028]
360        Point[7,000, 5,000] -> Point[5,086, 9,078]
361        Point[7,000, 4,900] -> Point[5,122, 9,005]
362        
363        test: should be a scaled identity matrix: = 
364        {{1.000000, -0.000000, -0.000000}, 
365        {0.000000, 1.000000, -0.000000}, 
366        {0.000000, 0.000000, 1.000000}}
367         */
368}
